caseTitle: MADAM AKUA NYAMEKYE v. MR. ANTHONY KWAKU OPOKU
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana dismissed an application by Madam Akua Nyamekye to review its prior 3-2 majority judgment dismissing her appeal regarding eligibility for the Krobo Stool. The applicant argued that the split decision and alleged miscarriage of justice warranted review under Rule 54 of the Supreme Court Rules (C.I. 16). The Court reaffirmed that review is not a second appeal and requires exceptional circumstances such as fundamental error or newly discovered evidence. The applicant merely rehashed arguments from the original appeal, including claims about dynastic rights and exclusivity under Akan customary law. The Court found no fundamental error, noting that evidence such as the installation of S.K. Mainoo (an Ekuona) and the acceptance of dwantoa from the respondent contradicted the claim of an exclusive dynasty. The application was dismissed for lacking merit.
citations: Quartey et als. vrs. Central Services Co. Ltd. et als. [1996-97] SGGLR 398
Mechanical Lloyd Assembly Plant vrs. Nartey [1987-88] 2 GLR 598
Kwa Nana vrs. Appa et al. (unreported) SC judgment dated 29th January, 1997
Republic vrs. Nana Oduro Numapau II, & 15 Ors., Ex-Parte: Nana Adu Ameyaw II, C.M. 39/99, dated 12th January, 2000
rationaleHighlights: Review is not a second appeal; only allowed under exceptional circumstances per Rule 54 of C.I. 16
Majority decision binds regardless of split; numerical disagreement does not justify review
Applicant failed to show fundamental error or new evidence
Arguments rehashed from appeal; no exceptional circumstances shown
Installation of S.K. Mainoo and acceptance of dwantoa undermine claim of exclusive dynasty
Court emphasized that review is not for rehearing or refining appellate arguments
Claim of displaced dynasty contradicted by post-Osei Sampam events
No constitutional or procedural error demonstrated
